[..]
> I was thinking =
about that. JavaScript is a functional language, but all of
> the JS test f=
rameworks that I am aware of use JUnit-like syntax for
> defining test case=
s (JsUnit defines test functions at global scope,
> JsTestDriver uses metho=
ds on a class). If functional programming could
> change the paradigm for d=
efining tests, you would think it would have
> happened in JavaScript.
> 
>=
 Am I missing something?

Whenever I checked with my limited understanding =
of JavaScript and its ecosystem I was extremely week on the unit testing si=
de of things.

Also the JS syntax doesn't lend itself to usage of closures =
as part of a DSL.

To be more specific. With ScalaTest FunSuites a test loo=
ks like this

test("a test testing something"){
// the actual test code
}

=
With Java8 I think it might look similar to this:

test("a test testing som=
ething"){ =3D>
// the actual test code
};

In JavaScript it would look more=
 or less like:

test("a test testing something", function(){
// the actual =
test code
});

In current Java:

test("a test testing something", new Runna=
ble{
    public void run(){
    // the actual test code
    }
});

I think =
one can identify some difference in verbosity, which might be part of the r=
eason why this style didn't become popular with JS.
